translation.text: Uniting with Himself, He bestows glorious greatness.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

author.author: Guru Amar Das
author.description:
Guru Amar Das [1479 - 1574] was the third Guru of the Sikhs, born at Basarke in Amritsar. His father, Tej Bhan and mother Bakht Kaur were orthodox Hindus. He became the oldest Sikh Guru.

Guru Amar Das put an end to tradition of sati, the burning of the widow on her husbands funeral pyre, and encouraged the remarriage of widows. He opened 22 preaching centres called Manjees and founded the town of Goindwal as the headquarters for the Sikh community.

translation.text: By Guru's Grace, one comes to know the Lord's worth.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

text: ਮਨਮੁਖਿ ਬਹੁਤੁ ਫਿਰੈ ਬਿਲਲਾਦੀ ਦੂਜੈ ਭਾਇ ਖੁਆਈ ਹੇ ॥੩॥

translation.text: The self-willed manmukh wanders everywhere, weeping and wailing; he is utterly ruined by the love of duality. ||3||

transliteration.text: manamukh bahut phirai bilalādī dūjai bhāi khuāī hē .3.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. translation.text: Egotism was instilled into the illusion of Maya.

translation.text: The self-willed manmukh is deluded, and loses his honor.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

text: ਗੁਰਮੁਖਿ ਹੋਵੈ ਸੋ ਨਾਇ ਰਾਚੈ ਸਾਚੈ ਰਹਿਆ ਸਮਾਈ ਹੇ ॥੪॥

translation.text: But one who becomes Gurmukh is absorbed in the Name; he remains immersed in the True Lord. ||4||

transliteration.text: guramukh hōvai sō nāi rāchai sāchai rahiā samāī hē .4.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. text: ਗੁਰ ਤੇ ਗਿਆਨੁ ਨਾਮ ਰਤਨੁ ਪਾਇਆ ॥

translation.text: Spiritual wisdom is obtained from the Guru, along with the jewel of the Naam, the Name of the Lord.

transliteration.text: gur tē giān nām ratan pāiā .

translation.text: Desires are subdued, and one remains immersed in the mind.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. text: ਆਪੇ ਖੇਲ ਕਰੇ ਸਭਿ ਕਰਤਾ ਆਪੇ ਦੇਇ ਬੁਝਾਈ ਹੇ ॥੫॥

translation.text: The Creator Himself stages all His plays; He Himself bestows understanding. ||5||

transliteration.text: āpē khēl karē sabh karatā āpē dēi bujhāī hē .5.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. translation.text: One who serves the True Guru eradicates self-conceit.

translation.text: Meeting with his Beloved, he finds peace through the Word of the Shabad.

text: ਅੰਤਰਿ ਪਿਆਰੁ ਭਗਤੀ ਰਾਤਾ ਸਹਜਿ ਮਤੇ ਬਣਿ ਆਈ ਹੇ ॥੬॥

translation.text: Deep within his inner being, he is imbued with loving devotion; intuitively, he becomes one with the Lord. ||6||

transliteration.text: antar piār bhagatī rātā sahaj matē ban āī hē .6.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. translation.text: The Destroyer of pain is known through the Guru.

translation.text: The Great Giver, the Life of the world, Himself has met me.

text: ਜਿਸ ਨੋ ਲਾਏ ਸੋਈ ਬੂਝੈ ਭਉ ਭਰਮੁ ਸਰੀਰਹੁ ਜਾਈ ਹੇ ॥੭॥

translation.text: He alone understands, whom the Lord joins with Himself. Fear and doubt are taken away from his body. ||7||

transliteration.text: jis nō lāē sōī būjhai bhau bharam sarīrah jāī hē .7.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. translation.text: He Himself is the Gurmukh, and He Himself bestows His blessings.

translation.text: Through the True Word of the Shabad, serve the True Guru.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. text: ਜਰਾ ਜਮੁ ਤਿਸੁ ਜੋਹਿ ਨ ਸਾਕੈ ਸਾਚੇ ਸਿਉ ਬਣਿ ਆਈ ਹੇ ॥੮॥

translation.text: Old age and death cannot even touch one who is in harmony with the True Lord. ||8||

transliteration.text: jarā jam tis jōh n sākai sāchē siu ban āī hē .8.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. translation.text: The world is burning up in the fire of desire.

translation.text: It burns and burns, and is destroyed in all its corruption.

text: ਮਨਮੁਖੁ ਠਉਰ ਨ ਪਾਏ ਕਬਹੂ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਬੂਝ ਬੁਝਾਈ ਹੇ ॥੯॥

translation.text: The self-willed manmukh finds no place of rest anywhere. The True Guru has imparted this understanding. ||9||

transliteration.text: manamukh thaur n pāē kabahū satigur būjh bujhāī hē .9.

translation.text: Those who serve the True Guru are very fortunate.

translation.text: They remain lovingly focused on the True Name forever.

text: ਅੰਤਰਿ ਨਾਮੁ ਰਵਿਆ ਨਿਹਕੇਵਲੁ ਤ੍ਰਿਸਨਾ ਸਬਦਿ ਬੁਝਾਈ ਹੇ ॥੧੦॥

translation.text: The Immaculate Naam, the Name of the Lord, permeates the nucleus of their inner being; through the Shabad, their desires are quenched. ||10||

transliteration.text: antar nām raviā nihakēval trisanā sabad bujhāī hē .10.

translation.text: Those who are imbued with the True Shabad are detached. Their comings and goings in reincarnation are ended. ||11||

author.author: Guru Amar Das
author.description:
Guru Amar Das [1479 - 1574] was the third Guru of the Sikhs, born at Basarke in Amritsar. His father, Tej Bhan and mother Bakht Kaur were orthodox Hindus. He became the oldest Sikh Guru.

Guru Amar Das put an end to tradition of sati, the burning of the widow on her husbands funeral pyre, and encouraged the remarriage of widows. He opened 22 preaching centres called Manjees and founded the town of Goindwal as the headquarters for the Sikh community.

text: ਸਤਿਗੁਰੁ ਅਪਣਾ ਸਦ ਹੀ ਸੇਵਹਿ ਹਉਮੈ ਵਿਚਹੁ ਜਾਈ ਹੇ ॥੧੨॥

translation.text: He serves his True Guru forever, and egotism is eradicated from within. ||12||

transliteration.text: satigur apanā sad hī sēvah haumai vichah jāī hē .12.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

author.author: Guru Amar Das
author.description:

Guru Amar Das put an end to tradition of sati, the burning of the widow on her husbands funeral pyre, and encouraged the remarriage of widows. He opened 22 preaching centres called Manjees and founded the town of Goindwal as the headquarters for the Sikh community.

text: ਗੁਰ ਤੇ ਬੂਝੈ ਤਾ ਦਰੁ ਸੂਝੈ ॥

translation.text: If one comes to understand, through the Guru, then he comes to know the Lord's Door.

transliteration.text: gur tē būjhai tā dar sūjhai .

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

Guru Amar Das put an end to tradition of sati, the burning of the widow on her husbands funeral pyre, and encouraged the remarriage of widows. He opened 22 preaching centres called Manjees and founded the town of Goindwal as the headquarters for the Sikh community.

translation.text: But without the Naam, one babbles and argues in vain.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

text: ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਸੇਵੇ ਕੀ ਵਡਿਆਈ ਤ੍ਰਿਸਨਾ ਭੂਖ ਗਵਾਈ ਹੇ ॥੧੩॥

translation.text: The glory of serving the True Guru is that it eradicates hunger and thirst. ||13||

transliteration.text: satigur sēvē kī vadiāī trisanā bhūkh gavāī hē .13.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

translation.text: When the Lord unites them with Himself, then they come to understand.

text: ਗੁਰ ਕੀ ਦਾਤਿ ਸਦਾ ਮਨ ਅੰਤਰਿ ਬਾਣੀ ਸਬਦਿ ਵਜਾਈ ਹੇ ॥੧੪॥

translation.text: One whose mind is filled with the Guru's gift forever - his inner being resounds with the Shabad, and the Word of the Guru's Bani. ||14||

transliteration.text: gur kī dāt sadā man antar bānī sabad vajāī hē .14.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. text: ਜੋ ਧੁਰਿ ਲਿਖਿਆ ਸੁ ਕਰਮ ਕਮਾਇਆ ॥

translation.text: He acts according to his pre-ordained destiny.

transliteration.text: jō dhur likhiā s karam kamāiā .

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. translation.text: No one can erase the Command of the Primal Lord.

text: ਸਤਸੰਗਤਿ ਮਹਿ ਤਿਨ ਹੀ ਵਾਸਾ ਜਿਨ ਕਉ ਧੁਰਿ ਲਿਖਿ ਪਾਈ ਹੇ ॥੧੫॥

translation.text: They alone dwell in the Sat Sangat, the True Congregation, who have such pre-ordained destiny. ||15||

transliteration.text: satasangat mah tin hī vāsā jin kau dhur likh pāī hē .15.

text: ਨਾਨਕ ਦਾਸੁ ਕਹੈ ਬੇਨੰਤੀ ਭੀਖਿਆ ਨਾਮੁ ਦਰਿ ਪਾਈ ਹੇ ॥੧੬॥੧॥

translation.text: Nanak, Your slave, offers this humble prayer; I stand at Your Door, begging for Your Name. ||16||1||

transliteration.text: nānak dās kahai bēnantī bhīkhiā nām dar pāī hē .16.1.

translation.text: Maaroo, Third Mehl:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None

text: ਏਕੋ ਰਵਿ ਰਹਿਆ ਸਭ ਅੰਤਰਿ ਤਿਸੁ ਬਿਨੁ ਅਵਰੁ ਨ ਕੋਈ ਹੇ ॥੧॥

translation.text: The One Lord is permeating and pervading, deep within the nucleus of all. Without Him, there is no other at all. ||1||

transliteration.text: ēkō rav rahiā sabh antar tis bin avar n kōī hē .1.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war.
